I really liked this book. It is very practical and interesting. It did remind me a little bit of The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business by Charles Duhigg. It included a lot less of the story telling, but included much of the advice of changing habits. It also reminded me of The Happiness Advantage: The Seven Principles of Positive Psychology That Fuel Success and Performance at Work by Shawn Achor. A really great book, that mentions adding friction to make it harder to go with bad habits (remove the remote control batteries, and it will probably make you think more about turning on the tv).  The author suggests that you should decide who is the person you want to be, and that habits make you who you are. Your habits shape your identity, and you can change your habits and identity (not sure that I am super happy with that phrasing, but there was much in the book that was really good, so I'll be willing to look away on this phrasing :)). I really loved his system: How to Create a Good HabitThe 1st law (Cue): Make it obvious.The 2nd law (Craving): Make it attractive.The 3rd law (Response): Make it easy.The 4th law (Reward): Make it satisfying.And:How to Break a Bad HabitInversion of the 1st law (Cue): Make it invisible.Inversion of the 2nd law (Craving): Make it unattractive.Inversion of the 3rd law (Response): Make it difficult.Inversion of the 4th law (Reward): Make it unsatisfying.It is worth mentioning that James Clear had a really terrible accident in baseball, and a serious head injury. He had been hit in the face with a baseball bat, and got into a comma. But this injury probably had a part of who he is today. This injury was one of mine, and the experience taught me a critical lesson: changes that seem small and unimportant at first will compound into remarkable results if you’re willing to stick with them for years. We all deal with setbacks but in the long run, the quality of our lives often depends on the quality of our habits. With the same habits, you’ll end up with the same results. But with better habits, anything is possible. His parents were no strangers to the hospital, since his sister had cancer a decade earlier. Oh my, poor parents.Clear puts an emphasis on starting, even with a little tiny easy thing. Habits for the most part is doing something that you started, whether it is sitting on the sofa, or going to the gym. Habits are like the entrance ramp to a highway. They lead you down a path and, before you know it, you’re speeding toward the next behavior. It seems to be easier to continue what you are already doing than to start doing something different. He gives the example of running starting with tying your running shoes.I really liked this book. Practical and nicely written, with some great advice. 4 stars.

I picked up this book because I am so deeply interested in the process of behavior change. There were some interesting insights that I’m finding helpful and immediately implementing, like “habit bundling” and optimizing my environment for the habits I want to promote, and the book covered a lot of strategies that I’ve already incorporated into my life, like habit tracking and maintaining a system for picking up or dropping habits (intention setting, manifesting and releasing with the full and new moon helps me). What’s standing out to me a lot is a lesson I’d already learned long before reading this book: “What is immediately rewarded is repeated. What is immediately punished is avoided.” Although this wasn’t the point of the book — which, like most self help books, lacked any analysis of how systems of oppression shape our conditions — this line made me reflect on how difficult it is for people to commit to ethical behaviors in a world that rewards oppressive behaviors. Clear writes too, though, about another lesson I’d already learned: “As soon as actions incur an immediate consequence, behavior begins to change… Behavior only shifts if the punishment is painful enough and reliably enforced. In general, the more local, tangible, concrete, and immediate the consequences, the more likely it is to influence individual behavior.” While I find it unfortunate that the author conflates punishments with consequences, I did find this insight valuable, and sort of affirming to read and reflect on.At the beginning of Chapter 15, I foolishly believed we were about to get a systemic analysis. Clear starts to write about Karachi, Pakistan in the 1990s where there was “no waste removal system, no electricity grid, and no clean water supply.” He writes, “The unsanitary conditions lead to widespread illness and disease. Contaminated water sources caused epidemics of diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Nearly one third of the children there were malnourished. With so many people crammed into such a small space, viruses and bacterial infections spread rapidly.” Reading all of this, there was no way NO WAY the author could be leading us into talking about anything but systemic solutions to systemic problems, right?? RIGHT?? Nope, the solution was….hand washing. Not just hand washing but hand washing the right way. I’m not trying to be dismissive here; he does say that there was a significant shift in the health of children in the neighborhood. And yet, I really thought he was so close to recognizing the limitations of hyper individualized solutions. That’s on me tho 😅

I don't often use stars anymore because I don't feel they accurately represent my thoughts on a book. This is the perfect example of why- don't take a 2 star to mean awful! Here is why ⬇️:The main ideas and principles of this book are incredibly important and I imagine helpful to many people. He does a great job of highlighting the importance of seeing the beauty and impact of focusing on small improvements that compound over time. I can absolutely see why this is such a leading book in the self help world.Also, I always love reading about fascinating studies in psychology or social experiments- who doesn't? My youtube history attests to how much I enjoy watching experiments on human behavior lol. If you enjoy stories and case studies that you would hear in the likes of a psychology class, you may especially like how he writes this book. Almost every chapter starts with one. If you don't like that? You will grow tired of those very quick.One thing that remains on my mind after finishing this is that he starts the book with personal background about an awful injury he suffered, and also how he ended up excelling in college by utilizing good habits. So I don't think it's wrong to assume the rest of the book would give details about the exact habits he used? Because... he doesn't. He gives several good strategies, yes, but I kept thinking, "cool, but what habits did YOU use that you said made you so successful in college?" Rather than relying on general scenarios of others using some of these habits, that would have added to this book a great deal since that is how he chose to kick off the book. It makes me question if his college success was purely from good habits as he says.I think the weak point of this book was in the execution. I think this book could have been much shorter, particularly due to its repetitive nature. That may just be a personal pet peeve though because perhaps my number one criticism about self help books I've read, is they could have been shorter. This also feels like a summary of other people's works and framed as his own ideas (like, literally renaming concepts that are already established.....kinda weird), rather than a new fresh take. And certain stories seemed to be really simplified to serve a particular idea, or I would wonder if it was even a good example to use for his point. Again, I may be overanalyzing here.In the end, I think this is an informative book about habits and the cognitive side behind them, and lays out useful strategies! However, the repetitiveness bogged down my enjoyment of this.

О ЧЕМ КНИГА:В одной книге Джеймс Клир собрал всё лучшее, что мы знаем на данный момент про привычки. Автор обобщил все научные знания когнитивной и поведенческой психологии. Эта работа основана на большом опыте Джеймса Клира по внедрению привычек в свою жизнь, а также постоянного изучения этой темы и практики внедрения у своих клиентов. В принципе, теперь после этой книги, про привычки можно больше ничего не читать.ГЛАВНАЯ МЫСЛЬ КНИГИ:Атомная привычка - это маленькая привычка, которая является частью большой системы. Для внедрения хороших привычек вам нужна система и правильное окружение.ЗАЧЕМ ЧИТАТЬ ЭТУ КНИГУ:- Чтобы получить эффективные и проверенные подходы для внедрения новых привычек в свою жизнь.МЫСЛИ И ВЫВОДЫ ИЗ КНИГИ:- Выстроить систему важнее, чем поставить цели. - Цель задает направление, а система - это способ с помощью которого я достигаю целей.- Постановка целей ориентирована на победу в игре. Построение системы ориентировано на то, чтобы продолжать играть и после победы.- За каждым изменением в привычках должно стоять убеждение в том, какой личностью я должен стать. Иначе это будет одноразовая попытка. Изменения должны проходить на уровне убеждений и моих представлений о самом себе.- Причиной сохранения привычки может быть только то, что привычка стала частью моей личности.- Надо разделить пространство квартиры четко по типам деятельности, которыми я там занимаюсь. Тоже самое надо сделать и с гаджетами. Каждое устройство только для определенного типа работы.- Люди, которые обладают, как нам кажется, выдающимся самоконтролем ничем не отличаются от обычных людей. За счет внедрения правильных привычек, они просто сделали так, что его практически не нужно применять.- Надо создать окружающую среду, где выработать и сохранить хорошие привычки было бы максимально просто. В долгосрочной перспективе, мы становимся продуктом среды, в которой живем.- Хороший игрок хочет победить в игре, в которую играют все остальные. Великий игрок сам создаёт игру, в которой у него максимальные шансы обыграть других. Надо создавать игру, где мой выигрыш предрешён заранее.ЧТО Я БУДУ ПРИМЕНЯТЬ:- Заведу «Журнал решений», где буду описывать причины, почему я принял эти решения и последствия и результаты, которые я от них ожидаю.ЕЩЕ НА ЭТУ ТЕМУ:Чарльз Дахигг «Сила Привычки»

I’m not a huge fan of the self-help genre, because so often the books sound the same or are new lists of “5 Things to Do Today that Will Change Your Life Forever,” and so forth. The writing tends to be serviceable at best and is centered on sports metaphors. Every now and then, however, a book in this category rises above the rest and really connects with me in just the right way. Atomic Habits, by James Clear, is one of those great ones.Essentially, Atomic Habits is an update of Charles Duhigg’s The Power of Habit and its idea of the “habit loop.” Clear argues that what’s most important in bringing about personal change is not our goals, but rather, the systems we put in place in order to achieve a goal. Goals come and go, but the systems we build along the way are the real key. Duhigg’s habit loop is four parts: cue, craving, response, reward. The key to forming better habits is to understand how these phases work. Clear breaks it into four “laws”: make it obvious; make it attractive; make it easy; make it satisfying. By understanding the habit loop and then building everyday systems that benefit from these four laws, change is much more likely. The changes are “atomic” because they are both very small and potentially very powerful.Clear is a good writer, having honed his craft for some years as a disciplined blogger on this topic. He does use occasional sports imagery (professional baseball is in his family background and his own life), but he also gives space to other sorts of metaphors and ways of life. The guidance he gives on change and habit-formation is completely sound and very encouraging. I recommend it to anyone, in any stage of life.

مين وصل ل500 كتاب نااااو✌***************لو قريت The Power Of habit اللي هو كان بابا المجال خلال ال10 سنين اللي فاتوا، فكنت هتلاقي فيه النموذج التقليدي بتاع العادة: Signal > Action > Reward.زي مثلا التدخين، بيبدأ بسيجنال التوتر مثلا او موقف فيه ضغط، بعدين تنفذ الاكشن اللي هو التدخين نفسه، بعدها تجيلك المكافأة اللي هي النيكوتين بتاع السجاير وارتخاء الأعصاب المؤقت.فكان النموذج التقليدي دي بيقولنا لو عايز تغير العادة، خليك واعي بالprocess دي وحاول اول ما السيجنال تظهر تخلي بالك وتشوفلك حاجة تانية تعملها تديك reward مكافئة أو شبه العادة اللي عايز تبطلها.أما عمنا جيمس كلير اللي كتابه في ظرف 3 سنين بس بقى بابا المجال الجديد، بيحاول يضيف للنموذج التقليدي layer جديدة اسمها الidentity.ممكن تحس إنه مكبر الموضوع سيكا، بس كل الغرض من النموذج الجديد بتاعه هو إن الidentity بتتكون على المدى البعيد من الحاجات اللي بتعملها كل يوم، وعشان كده عنوان الكتاب هو atomic habits في اشارة للعادات الصغيرة اوي اللي مش متشافة وبتتعمل كل يوم، وبعد فترة بيبقى ليها تأثير رهيب.وعلى رأي عمو جوردان بيترسون:Don't practice what you don't wanna become. A quick, easy read that discusses plenty of ideas around habit formation and how to stick with them. I’ve personally found a couple of them really helpful – one being that one of the best ways to getting started on a new habit is to ritualize the first two minutes of it. The idea being our resistance is mostly to getting started and once that’s passed it usually gets easier. This has been especially useful with my running – my plan was just to put on my running shoes without thinking too much. Of course, I don’t do that as often as I want, but it really is easier once you get started and that can be as simple as putting on your shoes. Another thing that I have trouble implementing but seems like a great idea - is to designate spaces for certain things. The example cited is of people who had trouble sleeping and how when they stopped using their phones in the bedroom, they found it easier to fall asleep. I’ve been trying to do that – a couple of days I left the phone in the living room and swore that I’ll never again bring it to my bedroom – but oh it’s so hard. There were a number of other things that I’d known about earlier, but reading them again in this book – which is so well organized – was still worth the while.

There are a lot of books on habits, but this is the best book on habits I've ever read! It breaks things down in a way that is based on research and actionable. A few things that stuck with me are:1) Whenever you do a habit, you are casting a vote for the person you want to become2) When you slip up, it's ok. You just have to make the next action you take, be one that is an action you want your ideal person to take3) A 1% improvement a day, can lead to a 37x improvement at the end of the year! (the compounding effect of habits)4) It's more important to show up than to actually get something done, because showing up is the hardest part (using activation energy to make yourself takes small steps to build your habit first)

Bullet Review:Good information (especially as I'm not super experienced in this realm of self-help), but once again, I worry about how unhealthy these habits could become (to me) in this "hustle culture" obsessed world that we live in. I already have enough problems in my own life, but managing to juggle recording a jillion habits and show constant improvement in them all seems like a recipe for disaster.That said, I think there are some great nuggets to be had in this, and as always, moderation moderation moderation.

TINY little incremental improvements add up to MIGHTY results.“If you’re having trouble changing your habits, the problem isn’t you. The problem is your system. Bad habits repeat themselves again and again not because you don’t want to change, but because you have the wrong system for change.You do not rise to the level of your goals. You fall to the level of your systems.Focusing on the overall system, rather than a single goal, is one of the core themes of this book. It is also one of the deeper meanings behind the word atomic. By now, you’ve probably realized than an atomic habit refers to a tiny change, a marginal gain, a 1 percent improvement. But atomic habits are not just any old habits, however small. They are little habits that are part of a larger system. Just as atoms are the building blocks of molecules, atomic habits are the building blocks of remarkable results.Habits are like the atoms of our lives. Each one is a fundamental unit that contributes to your overall improvement. At first, these tiny routines seem insignificant, but soon they build on each other and fuel bigger wins that multiply to a degree that far outweighs the cost of their initial investment. They are both small and mighty. This is the meaning of the phrase atomic habits—a regular practice or routine that is not only small and easy to do, but also the source of incredible power; a component of the system of compound growth.”~James Clear from Atomic HabitsJames Clear has a super popular website (jamesclear.com). Millions of people visit it every month and over two million subscribe to his email newsletter.After reading this book, I can see why.He’s a great writer and distills the essence of habit formation into, well, its fundamental components—the “atomic” structure if you will—while showing us how those TINY little incremental improvements add up to MIGHTY results. (We’ll talk about the math behind +1% daily gains in our first Big Idea.)Now, I rarely say a book is a must-read but this one’s as close as it gets.I’ve read, and featured via Philosopher’s notes, a lot of books on habits—from 
The Power of Habit
 and 
The Creative Habit
 to 
Superhuman by Habit
 and 
Mini Habits
. I enjoyed all of those and we had fun chatting about some of the best ideas in Habits 101 (and Willpower 101 and Optimizing Algorithms 101), but I’d say THIS book is the one to read for the best scientific overview of how habits work AND the best practical model to make that science work for you. I think you’ll love it. Get a copy here.The book is PACKED (!!!) with Big Ideas. It’s one of those books that is SO GOOD it’s really hard to distill into a six-page Note. We’ll barely scratch the surface of all the goodness, but I’m excited to share some of my favorites so let’s jump straight in!Some of my favorite big ideas from this book include:1. Tiny Changes - Remarkable results.2. Latent Potential - And its plateau.3. Identity - Literally: “repeated beingness.”4. The 4 Laws - Make it: Obvious + Attractive + Easy + Satisfying.5. The Sorites Paradox -Which coin makes you wealthy?I’ve summarized those Big Ideas in a Philosopher’s Notes TV episode that you can watch here. And I’ve added Atomic Habits by James Clear to my collection of Philosopher’s Notes--distilling the Big Ideas into 6-page PDF and 20-minute MP3s on 600+ of the BEST self-development books ever. You can get access to all of those plus a TON more over at heroic.us.

Hard to remember? Make it obvious. Don't feel like starting? Make it attractive. Too difficult? Make it easy.Don't feel like sticking with it? Make it satisfying. -all or nothing cycle of behaviour change is a common pitfall. Doing something is better than nothing. Do instead of plan-direct your goals to areas that excite you and match your natural skills. Align your ambition with your ability -habit stacking. Do a desired habit after something you already do-incentives start a habit. Identity sustains it-even though each incremental small action doesn't seem to make a difference, it does. If you put an ice cube out and turn the temperature up one degree at a time, that last degree that causes it to melt seems more important than all the ones before. But it isn't. The impact compounded-as habits become routine, they can become less interesting and less satisfying. Beware. Don't let boredom get you. Things with novelty cause excitement (junk food has culinary novelty, gambling has novelty due to unpredictable results, porn has sexual novelty, etc).-the tighter we cling to an identity, the harder it becomes to grow beyond it. Everything is impermanent. Periodically check in to see if your old habits and beliefs are still serving you.

حقیقتن این یه کتاب واقعن جالبه که زرد نیست!توی این کتاب نحوه عادت سازی یا حذف عادت بر حسب قوانین رفتار گرایی و شرطی سازی شرح داده شده و اگر بهش عمل کنید واقعن میتونه کارساز باشه.

کتاب بسیار شسته رفته و تمیز. واقعا لذت بردمکتاب شاید خیلی چیزای جدید نگه و نکاتی که میگه رو این‌ور و اون‌ ور شنیده باشید. ولی همینایی که میگه رو خیلی خوب جمع بندی کرده و یه راهنمای عملی و کاربردی میگه. واقعا اینش برام از همه چیز مهم تر بودمن کتاب رو تقریبا دوبار گوش دادم. و احتمالا بازم گوشش بدم. هربار که دارم ورزش میکنم اون بک‌گراند این کتاب داره حرف میزنه. و این خیلی به من انگیزه میده.مهمترین درسی هم که گرفتم این بود که شروع کنیم به ایجاد بهبود‌های کوچولو. جایزه‌ای که همین بهبود‌ها در نهایت میده اینقدر بزرگه که خودش باعث میشه تلاشمون بیشتر بشهاز طرفی یه تعریفی از عادت میکنه که خیلی برام جالب بود. برای من شبیه چیزی بود که توی دنیای کامپیوتر زیاد میبینم. چیزایی که شما مجبورید دستی انجام بدید معمولا کلی وقت میگیرن و همین باعث میشه که از کار اصلی وا بمونید. اگه یه برنامه بنویسید که کارا خودکار بشه. در عوض زمان و آزادی دارید که روی کارای مهم وقت بذارید. عادت‌سازی در حقیقت پروسه خودکار سازی کارهای لازمیه که هربار برای انجامشون کلی باید فکر کنید و زور بزنید انجام بدیمشون. ## What are habits?- cue – that indicates a possible change in state;- craving – a desire to reach or avoid that new state;- response – that increases the odds of satisfying the craving; and- reward – which satisfies the craving (and reinforces the cue).## Why is habit building important?- Reason 1: Changing our beliefs is a powerful way to change outcomes.- Reason 2: Some people fixate on goals (what; direction) when systems (how; inc. habits) are far more important:## How can I build and break habits effectively?1 – How to make habits obvious/invisible	- Visual – Vision is our most powerful sense; and	- Obvious – Make it easy to spot them2 – How to make habits attractive/unattractive	- “After [CURRENT HABIT], I will [HABIT I NEED].“	- “After [HABIT I NEED], I will [HABIT I WANT].“	Engineer your environment to minimise reliance on will-power and self-control:		- Move yourself someplace without competing/undesirable cues;		- Remove competing/undesirable cues from your environment;		- Fill your environment with your new/desirable cues; and		- Avoid creating contexts that trigger multiple habits.	Proactively manage band-wagon effect:		- Be aware that you have a strong natural desire to conform with:		- The close – the people directly around you;		- The many – the culture/society you immerse yourself in; and		- The powerful – the successful people you look up to.3 – How to make taking action easy:	- Show up and get started.4 – How to make habits satisfying:	- Design the habit so it’s satisfying to perform.	- Treat yourself to something you enjoy.	- Never miss twice – make a commitment to never miss two repetitions in a row.## How can I stay motivated when building habits?- Show up and stick to the schedule even if you don’t feel like it.- Pick the right metrics and monitor them- Never define yourself with things that can change.

There's got to be something that this guy does right. It might just be that he’s found the proper mix of real world examples, easy to apply manual-like instructions and just the right amount of brain science to get his point across.Of course, now that I think about it, I guess that the cocktail he made here will appeal to certain types of personalities more than to others, and I'm not even going to try to guess which, since I don't really know where I stand to begin with. Heck, maybe I'm the kind of people that it appeals to: those who can't be bothered to do some introspection. Or better yet, who do introspect, but never reach an actionable conclusion. But enough about that. The point is, if you feel that you might need a bit more order and structure in your life, or if you're annoyed that you can't stick to healthy or productive habits, then this might actually help. For me, there were at least a few takeaways. One thing that I'm pondering is how to design my environment to help me stick with a habit. And it's as easy as placing a glass full of water on the nightstand before you go to bed if you want to drink water first thing in the morning. Another cool trick is using down-time to do small chores. Like cleaning the toilet while you wait for the water in the shower to get warmer. You're already there in the bathroom and doing nothing, might as well make the most of it.That said, there are also some weaker parts. He does have a few moments throughout the book where he feels the need to do some life coaching, which, in my opinion, he could have scrapped. I always feel that funny moments are more memorable than personal confessions (and the confessions here never stop), so I would have liked more jokes instead. But, then again, not everybody can make jokes work, so, I guess that, here too, he plays to his strengths. (or avoids his weaknesses)Good book, easy read and just about the right length. Now I’ve got to find a good place to put some weights so I can stumble over them in the morning. (#workoutgoals)

Impactful book, practical too which is nice. Great book on how to create of break habits.I Atomic Habits useful as I did with the book Deep Work by Cal Newport in the sense that both are about improving productivity. Deep Work was more impactful to me though as some things in Atomic Habits were repeated from other books I've read like The Power of Habit by Charles Duhigg. Power of Habit was more so the importance and impact habits have on you, as oppose to Atomic Habits which I found more practical in the sense that how you can make or break productive or unproductive habits. It also reminded me of the Compound Effect by Darren Hardy because of how he talks a lot about how little changes in your daily routine can make a big impact down the line, and about compound interest.Notes:- Change your identity change your habits - not I’ll try and run, instead say I am a runner and I’m going for a run. Look at what you want and ask yourself what type of person would I have to be to get to that and adopt traits and habits that go with that type of person- Every goal has systems in place. It’s the systems that you can always adapt and change. What, When and where?- Habits are automatic, you don’t even think about it.- Cue - Craving - Response - Reward- Cue is first indication to remind you, a trigger - noticing- Crave is desire and motivation of the reward. - wanting- Response is a thought or action which is the habit - obtaining- Reward is the end goal - Satisfy the craving.- Use 4 laws to create a good habit - cue make it obvious, craving - make it attractive, response - make it easy, reward - make it satisfying- Use 4 laws to break a bad habit - cue make it invisible, craving make it unattractive, response make it difficult, reward make it unsatisfying- Remove the cue to the craving, remove the craving- Environment is very important, your closest friends and family have great influence on your habits - because it's "normal""

Burned once again by the bestseller lists.I've read this book through gritted teeth only because I'm trying, really hard, to build a few habits of my own at the moment: not to give up on books because I disagree with the writer's politics, for instance.This is one of those books that could have easily been condensed into a long-form essay. I think that the core ideas here, i.e. ways to maintain your habits, could indeed be useful to a lot of people including me. But beyond these ideas there's a lot of fluff:Countless ruminations on human nature which are just opinions masquerading as facts. "Improving our odds of survival and reproduction are the deeper motives behind everything we do.", "Until you work as hard as those you admire, don't explain away their success as luck.", and, referring to a Seneca quote in one of the worst takes I've ever read, "Being poor is not having too little, it is wanting more."Or the quotes attributed to the writer's own role-models of success: Warren Buffett, Scott Adams, and Naval Ravikant as always with his self-evident truisms like "The trick to doing anything is first cultivating a desire for it." or "To write a great book, you must first become the book." Of course I'm cherry-picking here: these are just the points in the book where I came close to giving up.What I guess I'm trying to say is that reading this book could be a pleasurable experience for those who align with these opinions and look up to these people, but I sympathize with others like me who sat through it constantly having to filter out all the superfluous garbage.

Creo que lo que más me gustó del libro es que aterrizó todo de forma práctica y sencilla. No es un libro que te ponga metas imposibles, sino que lleva todo a un nivel manejable y explica por qué lo hace. Hábitos atómicos no entrega secretos ni fórmulas mágicas, nada de lo que dice te va a hacer explotar el cerebro, pero creo que eso es lo interesante, que todo lo que dice hace sentido porque es sencillo y lógico.Algo curioso fue que mucho de lo que el libro decía yo ya lo aplicaba, como dije, todo era lógico y hacía sentido. Yo usaba su técnica para crear hábitos y rutinas sanas y la verdad es que soy buena manteniéndolas, este libro lo que hizo fue explicarme por qué algunos hábitos los mantuve mejor que otros.Creo que es útil y con buenos tips, no es uno de esos libros que pretende vender algo profundo, pero en realidad es solo humo y ninguna forma de aplicarlo de forma realista. Tiene buenos tips, además de explicaciones detalladas de cómo aplicarlos e incluso tablas para descargar y rellenar.Otra cosa que me gustó, fue que explicó con ejemplos reales varias cosas. Algunos experimentos, ejemplos de equipos de algún deporte y otros grupos, por medio de estos ejemplos fue demostrando los puntos que presentó en su libro. Lo que ayudó a reforzar lo que decía y mostrar que ciertas cosas con cambios pequeños podían provocar grandes cambios.No tengo mucho más que decir de Hábitos atómicos, me pareció un buen libro, con consejos prácticos y realista, además de buenas explicaciones detrás de cada uno.

An incredible read outlining the importance of tiny habits. Everyone is aware of the long term impact of small healthy habits, but the real struggle is the continued application of the same. This book lists down really easy, but impactful steps one can take to ensure consistency. Be it getting fitter, honing your skills, have more impactful relationships, get rid of an addiction, gain mastery in a subject - James Clear provides a simple and facile framework at our disposal. I used to think that having a set routine will take out the excitement from life; but it doesn't need to work that way. One can be spontaneous and accustomed to a routine at the same time. The areas of applicability of the two are different; for example, routine in learning and exercising, spontaneous in art and travel. A person can be both structured and creative. I did not give a perfect 5 because these are ideas which weren't very new to me; but the book brings them all together and provides a foundational tool on how to apply the same to create a better life.I am looking forward to applying the valuable lessons learnt in daily life!

يعرفنا "جيمس كلير" في هذا الكتاب مدى أهمية و فائدة العادات الذرية وكيفية تقويتها وتحسينها و التخلص من العادات السيئة و الانتظام على ذلك ،يقول جيمس في هذا الكتاب ان اي شخص يمكن ان يصبح عظيم،عن طريق الاهتمام و الانتظام على تقوية و تفعيل العادات الذرية.عندما بدأت في قراءة الكتاب كنت أشعر أنني وجدث المحتوى الذي كنت ابحث عنه في هذا الموضوع،.لكن للاسف لم أجد هذا الشخص الذي مر بالكثير من التجارب في حياته سيكون هذا الكتاب بالنسبة له بديهي و غير مفيد بعض الشيء ،كما أن الكاتب لم يقل شيء جديد في هذا الكتاب و جميع الموضوعات مكررة لم اتعرف على شيء جديد الا القليل.لا أنكر أني استفدت من هذا الكتاب في بعض المواضيع مثلاَ:1-أن أركز على العادات و تحسينها قبل الهدف نفسه .2-ان انظم عاداتي و استمر في تقويتها3-كانت الأمثلة الموجودة في هذا الكتاب جيدة حقاًلم تكن الاستفادة من هذا الكتاب مثلما كنت اتوقع بصراحة

I liked the simplicity of this book and the well conceived chapters detailing how to "build good habits and break bad ones" Yes, alot of this was common sense and would have also been in similar books using different phrasing, but I liked the use of his personal stories and those of friends and other people listed in this book. I also appreciated the various charts he used throughout the book and this does make for easy reference points. I personally do not do any type of journaling he mentions, but I should start so I can track the various goals (fitness, eating habits, to name two) I did purchase this book in order for me to refer back to it when I feel things are taking a step backwards.Recommend for those looking to change their outlook at this time.

Creating healthy habits is the ultimate challenge of modern people with so many distractions, easy-to-reach pleasures and endless alternatives. It provides good insight to make positive changes in life but it is difficult to leave the comfort zone and put into practice. One of the best books that I’ve read on habits that can produce effective results if followed. What it basicly suggests is that taking small but steady steps towards a well-defined goal is more effective than having unrealistic vague targets like being rich, super athletic or healthy. Well, I am curious to find out where it will lead me, I am happy to have invested my time into this.

Knygoje pateikti metodai, kurie veikia. Man patiko. Autorius taip atsakingai viską sudėliojo knygoje, lyg nuoširdžiai norėtų kad mums pavyktų :) 🖋️ Sėkmę lemia ne vienkartiniai gyvenimo pokyčiai, o kasdieniai įpročiai.🖋️ Jei jums sunku pakeisti savo įpročius, problema - ne jūs. Problema - sistema.🖋️ Norint tapti geriausia savo versija, reikia nuolat koreguoti savo įsitikinimus ir tobulėti.🖋️ Kiekvienas veiksmas - tai asmenybės, kokia norite tapti, rinkimasis.🖋️ Pradžia nuo nulio motyvuoja.🖋️ Tokie veiksmai kaip "daugiau skaityti" ar "sveikiau maitintis" yra socialiai reikšmingi, bet neaišku, kaip ir kada reikėtų jų imtis, kad jie tiksliai būtų įgyvendinti. Formuluokite konkrečiai ir aiškiai.🖋️ Lai jus supa žmonės, turintys tokius įpročius, kokius norite išsiugdyti ir jūs.🖋️ Dažniausiai klausiama, kiek laiko reikia naujam įpročiui išsiugdyti. Iš tiesų žmonės turėtų klausti, kiek kartų reikia, kad būtų išsiugdytas naujas įprotis.🖋️ Efektyviausia mokymosi forma yra praktikavimasis, o ne planavimas. 🖋️ Pertvarkykite savo pasaulį taip, kad svarbiausi veiksmai taptų ir lengviausiai atliekami.🖋️ Negaliu būti tobulas, bet galiu išvengti antrosios klaidos.🖋️ Problema manyti, kad jei ko nors negalite padaryti idealiai, tuomet geriau to nedarysite apskritai. Venkite nedaryti nieko.🖋️ Įpročių stebėjimas ir kiti vaizdūs vertinimo būdai gali padėti įpročius padaryti malonius, nes matysite aiškius padarytos pažangos įrodymus.🖋️ Sėkmė ne tikslas, kurį reikia pasiekti.. Tai sistema, kurią reikia tobulinti, begalinis procesas, kurį būtina nuolat gerinti.🖋️ "Laimė - tai laikotarpis tarp vieno troškimo, kuris jau išsipildė, ir kito, kuris dar formuojasi."🖋️ Jei nuolat kalbate apie tai, kad jums svarbus vienas ar kitas dalykas, bet nieko dėl to nedarote, iš tikrųjų to nenorite. Laikas atvirai pasikalbėti su savimi. Veiksmai parodo tikruosius jūsų motyvus.

“𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐬𝐞𝐞𝐦 𝐬𝐦𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐭 𝐟𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐝 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐨 𝐫𝐞𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐤𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐭𝐬 𝐢𝐟 𝐲𝐨𝐮’𝐫𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐤 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐲𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐬.“In Atomic Habits, James Clear offers a remarkable approach to the shifting of grotesque habits and highlights the utter importance and awareness of the ever-changing minuscule "atomic habits" that can change lives in a drastically wonderful and successful way. This book is broken into 5 descriptive segments discussing the inner workings of positive and negative habit formations and offers a realistic and ground-breaking perspective emphasizing the incorporation of the littlest habits that can transform routines in an "atomic" way, providing a rapid path to greater efficiency, success, and overall growth.James Clear dives in-depth by explaining the complexities of human behavior, psychology, and neurology. By offering astounding examples of the massive impacts that develop from smaller positive actions in everyday life, he helps visualize how this can completely change a person’s outlook, personality, future, and response to various situations in an extraordinarily metamorphic fashion. Atomic Habits provides a steady read enabling sensible, constructive insight and thought. No matter the goals, this book is an extremely useful tool and provides motivation to start the habit-forming or habit-changing process. A hugely beneficial must-read. 5-stars.

الأهداف الكبيرة والنتائج المذهلة التي نحققها في حياتنا ماهي إلا عبارة عن مجموعة من العادات الصغيرة التي نقوم بتأديتها يومياً، ولكن بدلاً من التركيز على عاداتنا فقط يجب التركيز على النظام المتبع أو الطريق الصحيح للوصول إليها.يتحدث الكاتب هنا عن أربعة قوانين متبعة لبناء العادات الحسنة والتخلص من العادات السيئة وهي:لبناء العادات الحسنة:1/ إجعلها واضحة.2/ إجعلها جذابة.3/ إجعلها سهلة.4/ إجعلها مشبعة.للتخلص من العادات السيئة:1/ إجعلها خفية.2/ إجعلها غير جذابة.3/ إجعلها صعبة.4/ إجعلها غير مشبعة.الفصل الأخير يتحدث عن علاقة النجاح والتميز بالوراثة وكيفية إختيار عادات ومسارات في حياتنا تناسب شخصياتنا...💡 رأيي الشخصي:الكتاب فعلاً عملي للغاية سيغير نظرتك نحو العديد من العادات اليومية التي تمارسها، وستكتشف أنك أصبحت بعد قرائته أكثر نضجاً وإستيعاباً للكثير مما يدور حولك.ستضع خططاً ناجحة ومميزة لحياتك بناءاً على عادات تمارسها يومياً وتتقنها

My rating 4.5 star!You guys remember two years ago when I gushed about The Power of Habit and how much I recommend for people to read it?Well, this one is even better. If reading The Power of Habit makes us understand 'habit' better, Atomic Habits provides practical methods and solutions that are research-based.It's an easy to understand book/manual, with case studies and examples of real life people. At the end of each chapter, there's simplified notes for easy reference.If you want to step up your game on creating a disciplined and successful life, I suggest you go and read Atomic Habits. But, do read The Power of Habit first. I feel that your habit journey will not be complete without reading these two books.

'Atomic Habits' is a great book with useful practical tools/methods to improve different aspects of your life - with the main underpinning theme being: changes/improvements could be tiny or 'atomic' but, nevertheless, crucial over the long-run.One useful discussion was: the importance on working on the 'system/infrastructure' before working on the habits itself. You may set some goals/objectives and get pumped and achieve them for some period but then you see yourself back to 'square one' - as probably we failed to work on the ecosystem or the infrastructure (which remained an obstacle rather than an enabler to the change). The ecosystem should be working in your favor (it shouldn't be that we need to exert so much of 'will-power' everytime we need to achieve something).

সচরাচর মোটিভেশনাল বই পড়া হয় না। একটা কোম্পানির রিক্রুটমেন্ট টেস্টের অংশ হিসেবে বইটা পড়া লাগল। বঙ্গদেশে এই প্রথম দেখলাম একটু ভিন্নধর্মী স্টাইল। যাই হোক, গতানুগতিক মোটিভেশনাল বইগুলো থেকে অনেকটা ভিন্নধারার বই৷ মানুষের জীবনের অপরিহার্য অংশ হ্যাবিট কিংবা অভ্যাস কে ভেঙ্গে ভেঙ্গে ব্যাখ্যা করেছেন ভদ্রলোক। জেমস ক্লিয়ার সাহেব ছোটবেলায় বেজবল খেলতে গিয়ে ভয়ংকর ইঞ্জুরি তে পড়েন। সচরাচর অন্য কেউ হলে ঐখানেই ক্যারিয়ারের ইতি হতে পারত। কিন্তু, তিনি নিজের অভ্যাসের জোরে ডেনিসন ইউনিভার্সিটির বেস্ট অ্যাথলেট মনোনীত হন। ইএসপিএন এর ঘোষিত পুরো যুক্তরাষ্ট্রের সেরা ৩৩ খেলোয়াড়ের তালিকায়ও স্থান হয় উনার। ভিন্ন ভিন্ন উদাহরণ কিংবা কাহিনীর মারফতে মানবচরিত্রের অনেক অভ্যাসের ই বর্ণনা করেছেন তিনি। বিশ্ববিখ্যাত সাঁতারু মাইকেল ফেলেপস থেকে শুরু করে সাইকিয়াট্রিস্ট, ফিজিশিয়ান অনেকের উদাহরণ ও টেনে এনেছেন। বিগিনারদের জন্য বেশ ভাল বই। তবে, লেখার সাবলীলতায় খারাপ লাগেনাই পড়তে।

A Journey of a Thousand Miles Begins with a Single StepEver wondered how small, seemingly insignificant actions can lead to monumental changes in your life? James Clear's Atomic Habits is a testament to the power of tiny, incremental changes, or as he calls them, "atomic habits".The Power of Tiny ChangesAtomic Habits is a practical guide that teaches readers how to form good habits and break bad ones. Clear's approach is rooted in the idea that small habits make a big difference. He emphasizes the significance of small, manageable adjustments in daily routines, which compound over time to create significant and lasting results.The book presents a system for habit formation, focusing on four key strategies: making the habit obvious, attractive, easy, and satisfying. Clear argues that people are driven by unconscious habits and thoughts, and positive change cannot take place until we identify our operating beliefs and thought processes.A Practical GuideAtomic Habits is not just a theoretical exploration of habit formation. It's a practical guide filled with actionable advice. Clear provides readers with a set of simple rules for creating good habits and breaking bad ones, making the book an invaluable resource for anyone seeking to understand the mechanics of habit formation and change.Final ThoughtsAtomic Habits is useful for those looking to build a solid foundation for lasting change. It's an insightful book that provides practical strategies for creating positive habits and breaking destructive ones. Clear's engaging writing style demystifies the process of habit formation and guides readers on a transformative journey.In conclusion, Atomic Habits is a book that will reshape the way you think about progress and success, and give you the tools and strategies you need to transform your habits, and ultimately, your life.

These are the things I learnt (some in my words, some in the words of the author) from the book Atomic Habits by James Clear. Read this 300 page book only if you are willing to make changes to your life. As often it happens with non fiction books, specifically self help, they are just read and not followed. Then the genre of self help as a whole is cursed for not being good enough. My review of this book would be a mixed one. It’s very informative sure but subconsciously, we already know these things. At least, I found myself knowing a lot of it. It’s just the application part wherein we lack. Some concepts are really interesting. I do have a controversial comment to add though, if someone would've been able to make changes to their life as ask to, why would one be needing or reading this book? Sure, it would serve to be a good guide but this isn't something one can do in a day or week. It requires consistency, sheer consistency and awareness. For those who want to understand the habits and it’s science, I’ll recommend this else, I’ll just say, • Sit down • Observe and try to understand why you do what you do • Have a clear goal• Work on that goal by changing your behaviour and habits. We already know a lot about ourselves. For beginners, it's a book quite interesting. Do read!

We often heard people discussing about how hard work is primarily important for attaining success in life. But never do they tell exactly how the first step should be taken. How should one deal with one's fears and insecurities. And what about the fluctuating motivation one used to experience repeatedly. Applauding a person when he or she has reached the peak of mountain is good. However, willing to scrutinize their trekking strategy and learning from their determination of continuing the arduous journey is something that should be taken more seriously. I first came to know about the competency of developing a good habit after reading the widely acclaimed book by Charles Duhigg. That book really blowed my mind. And now after three months of having gone through that book, i came across another powerful book on habits. As i have already gone through the wonderful ratings and reviews of my fellow friends, i was quite sure about the gratification which i would have received on picking this one. And now after spending more than a week on this book, i can delightfully vouch for its worthiness.At the mere age of twenty-one, James Clear had got into an accident, where he got smacked on his face by a baseball bat, which in turn put a question mark on his baseball career, something he has always aspire for. After going through the consequential series of disappointment and frustration, he, one day, decided to come out of the sorrowful phase his life was gradually into. In the first year of his college, he started reflecting on the small and negligible behavior that encompasses the major hours of his every day. He made little changes and inculcate some easy and significant habits in his daily routine. Overtime he experienced a discernible change in his productivity and efficiency. Not only did he participated in the game, but also won the first prize of the college tournament. With an intention of sharing his life experience with all, he began writing blogs and later published this book.This book deals with all the questions that bugs our mind whenever we decide to adopt a new habit. The author has addressed all the issues relating to lack of motivation, boredom, self control, staying committed to one goal, missing on some days and finding joy in continuing. He has also shared techniques and methods like Habit stacking, environment design, habit scorecard and temptation building for dealing with the above mentioned issues. And not the forget the four laws of behavior change, which he delineated in great detail. I specially like the third aspect of behavior change, in which he stressed on making identity-based change rather than outcome based. This is an outstanding work which particularly focuses on the ways and methods of inculcating a good habit and breaking a bad one.

I really enjoyed this book. I wound up listening the audiobook and following along with the hard copy. I found it very helpful to *hear* the book and this was a great preview of sorts because even though I marked up my physical copy now I plan to do back to dial into the sections that I want to apply to my life and that I know will be impactful.I'm learning that with some self-help books I benefit by reading the whole book and then going back to put it into action vs. trying to take action steps as I go along. I have a much better perspective at the end of the book.James Clear narrates the audio and for the most part I found the content very accessible and universal. I'm less interested in the science behind why we can't sustain habits - just tell me what to do thank you very much. Haha!It felt good to hear that I have some good foundational habits in some areas and it was also a screaming reminder of how I let some of my good habits go (like my habit tracker) and I definitely learned some new tips and strategies.Overall I've found this to be one of the more universally helpful books in that it's general enough that anyone can apply it to their lives but it also has specific steps and metrics that you can implement. It's also not overwhelming - the core message of this book is to take small steps and make small, attainable shifts. Those efforts will compound and grow over time. The best example is when he talks about wanting to get in shape - your initial goal shouldn't be to work out 5 days a week for 1 hour at a time. The first step is just to put your sneakers on. Then it's 5 minutes. That's all. It's all about building a foundation and adding to it. I love this philosophy. I like the structure of the book and love a chapter ending that summarizes the highlights so I know which chapters to dive back into. I've had this book on my shelf for nearly a year and am so glad I finally picked it up. Change. Starts. Here.

The best book to begin any year, I would love to come back to it time and again. This book talks about the importance of atomic habits, how to build and sustain good ones and avoid bad ones. The basic idea is to - (1) Be aware of our current habits - we can do this by tracking/reviewing ourselves daily.(2) Identify the habits that are working for us and the ones that aren't.(3) The author describes the stages of habit forming as (a) Cue, (b) Craving (c) Response (d) Reward(4) The book contains several examples to make these 4 stages very clear to understand.(5) For any habit that we want to retain or create newly - we should try and be creative at all stages of habit forming. Which includes - Cue --> Make it Obvious Craving --> Make it attractiveResponse --> Make it easyReward --> Make it Satisfying(6) And for bad habits that we would like to get rid of, we should try and do the opposite - Cue --> Make it InvisibleCraving --> Make it UnattractiveResponse --> Make it difficultReward --> Make it UnsatisfyingI found the following poem in the book very inspiring:Men are born soft and supple;dead, they are stiff and hard.Plants are born tender and pliant;dead, they are brittle and dry.Thus whoever is still and inflexibleis a disciple of death.Whoever is soft and yielding is a disciple of life.The hard and stiff will be broken.The soft and supple will prevail.May we all find the strength to embrace change and stay soft and supple all our lives! A very happy new year 2022 to all my fellow readers ❤️ Also, I have started an initiative to create positivity using my YouTube Channel, do check it out if you are native Hindi/Tamil speakers : https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCcQs...Would love to hear all your feedbacks!

This was excellent. Full of common sense advice on how to change your habits, one tiny step at a time. The ideas are simple and easy to follow, and he gives concrete examples and even templates for things like habit tracking and evaluating your habits. James Clear also explains the psychology behind his system, sprinkled with interesting, but not too many, real life examples. For example, we are wired for immediate satisfaction, but most good habits have delayed gratification - so he suggests finding an immediate reward. Some simple techniques are habit stacking - i.e. connecting a new habit to an existing one, or the 2 minute rule - that a new habit should not take longer than two minutes. First, establish the habit, later refine or add to it. Very useful. I have listened to it, but ordered a copy and will review it in print, so I can make notes. Highly recommend to every procrastinator out there - of whom I am a major example.

Una lectura imprescindible para tomar consciencia de los hábitos que componen no sólo nuestro día a día sino aquellos que tenemos automatizados desde pequeños y que contribuyen a crear lo que concebimos como nuestra identidad. James Clear nos propone, en términos claros, una noción honesta y directa acerca de la importancia de las acciones que pueden parecer diminutas o insignificantes y cómo éstas actúan en realidad como determinantes de nuestros resultados a largo plazo. Los hábitos son, en última instancia, los que nos alinean con el éxito o el fracaso.Además de ejemplos, conceptos y análisis acerca del tema, el autor nos provee de un sencillo método de 4 pasos para integrar nuevos hábitos a nuestra vida en función de lo que queramos lograr. Profundiza, además, en tips para que estas aplicaciones resulten más efectivas y perdurables incluso para el individuo poco motivado.

Es frecuente que los libros de divulgación, en el afán del autor por hacerlos comprensibles, pierdan rigurosidad; el extremo opuesto son los intentos de que sean una muestra de científicidad, y en esa búsqueda se vuelven poco digeribles, aburridos, unos completos ladrillos. James Clear encuentra el equilibrio perfecto en Hábitos Atómicos: ciencia amena, aprendizaje y deleite. El título sirve de introducción, desde él imaginamos de qué va. Empezamos conociendo la mecánica de los hábitos y su importancia en el comportamiento humano. La mayor parte del libro desarrolla un paso a paso para instaurar nuevos y mejores hábitos, y para eliminar aquellos inconvenientes. Por lo tanto, el libro resulta sumamente práctico aportando acciones puntuales de mejora. Además de útil, se disfruta mucho.

5 Star Knowing that one should look upon one’s habit is one thing, but to get the answer like “What”, “When”, “Where” and “How”- is what the book “Atomic Habit” does. The book has a plethora of real-life events that portray “Habits are like compound interest”. James started with his own-not-so-happy-incident from his life and how subsequently he went on to the quest of creating the Atomic Habits empire.The essence of the whole book is put into a nutshell of four life-defining rule:•	Make it Obvious (Cue)•	Make it Attractive (Craving)•	Make it Easy (Response)•	Make it Satisfying (Reward)To achieve big in life it’s not necessary that we do only big things. A small percentage of improvement on a daily basis can also achieve the same thing. One has to overcome his/her “Plateau of Latent Potential”- as the author suggests. It’s good to have goals in life but do not focus on goals rather accrue your potential to create a “belief system” to achieve that goal. Winners and Losers have the same goals but what differentiates them is “System” they followed to get the goal.Every rule begins with a spellbound example from the annals of successful history. Be it entertainment, sports, medicine, scholar – every example is so inter-related with the habit that it feels unbelievable that a minute habit can have a remarkable impact. James also gave few strategies to practice this in our daily life like “Habit Score Card”, “Habit Stacking”, “Habit Contract” and many more. One of my fav. concepts from the book is “The Goldilocks Rule”: It says, “The human brain loves a challenge, but only if it is within an optimal zone of difficulty.”The amazing thing I liked in the book is how meticulously James observed the nuance in once behaviors. How one’s habit gets created and shaped in the society he/she lives, whom they talk, whom they listen, and what object they use. The book is not targeted only for a particular sect of society but it encapsulates the whole of mankind. I think this is the book one must have on their shelf.

AHH! Im not one to pick up a self-help book and get through it, but thank u for inspiring me to finish this one @Claire. Couldn’t recommend a read more going into the new year. James Clear is completely candid about the realities of human nature and human behavior in a way that makes you trust what he has to say. He provides a swath of information from a wide range of fields including neuroscience, biology, psychology, etc. to explain how and why our brains work the way they do and how and why we can face anticipated challenges based on how we are wired to work. From here, Clear gives us solution-oriented, practical, and evidence-based solutions to begin rewiring our brains to build healthy habits and break unhealthy ones (he even links to tangible tools on his website to begin planning/ implementing your own path to GREATNESS if you want). Lastly, I loved how there were countless examples of professional sports teams, business executives, medical professionals, artists and celebrities, etc. embodying the techniques Clear references with much to show after the fact. I am an all or nothing person, but this book made me realize that it’s not how fast, large, or specific your goals are that make them great. It’s about how consistent you show up for yourself, how aligned with your identity and how obvious, attractive, easy, and rewarding your habits are that can make you successful. BOOM.

I generally tend to avoid reading self-help books because I believe its more natural to learn from your own past experiences rather than someone else's, which is why I always found it difficult to relate to, and apply the lessons written by self-help authors. However, reading this book was certainly a different experience. The author provides a cogent, and a scientific approach, unlike the philosophical approach of most self-help books. He breaks down the formation/destruction of good/bad habits into easy-to-understand and easy-to-apply systematic components. This book also taught me a lot on how the human psyche works in tandem with our environment. He talks about how our brain is wired to overvalue radical changes in our behaviour as against the undervaluation of small changes over a longer period of time, which was the most important lesson I picked up from this book. A must-read for anyone who wants to form/break good/bad habits. However, I'd suggest to read only a few pages everyday so that you are able to apply those learnings as you go along. Reading this book like a story book and aiming to apply everything after completing it in its entirety will probably do you no good.

Some generic advice and platitudes. But also some practical tips on creating habits and routines. He suggests habit stacking and habit tracking. I still wish he would have described more examples throughout. He discusses how genes affect abilities, but I wish he would have described more thoroughly ideas like internal vs. external locus of control and fixed vs. growth mindset.

I highly recommend listening to this one! Felt like an informative podcast and was so engaging. There is so much to chew on and I appreciate that Clear has so many resources on his website to spell out these concepts and make them more palpable. I love the idea that small changes and shifts in our mindset really can bring about so much transformation. Also if you want the main ideas of this book presented in 30 minutes from a gentler perspective that feels like a chat with your older sister, just listen to the Lazy Genius episode, “How To Lazy Genius Your Habits.”

DNF at 15%I picked this up as my next audiobook for 2021 but I have no desire to continue listening to it for multiple reasons.First, the book starts with an incredibly gruesome and graphic account of that time the author got hit in the face by a baseball bat and almost died. As someone that's somewhat squeamish, listening to him tell me that his eye flew out of his socket when he sneezed put me off straight away from the start. That's a warning that I wish I got before actually starting this book.Even so, I decided to read a bit more and see what its like when he actually gets to the habits bit. Needless to say, disappointing. There's only so many times I can listen to "Available at www.atomichabits.com" before I start rolling my eyes. We get it, you have an incredibly successful productivity website. You don't need to mention it every other page. Repetitiveness of ideas also seems to be the basis of this book. I think he said the words "goals" and "system" around 50 times in 30 min, which really showed me that this book is way too long and that the point he is trying to get across could be made in a few bullet points instead. Reading some other reviews, its clear that I already got the main ideas of this book without even getting to 50%.Also, one of my biggest pet peeves is when people make metaphors that are meant to be deep but really they could describe a number of things. The first one that comes to mind is when he talks about the success "threshold" or "plateau". He compares it to a sculptor hitting a rock a 100 times and only splitting it on the 101st hit. This is just a personal preference but I just don't like it when people compare situations as if they're identical when trying to make a point. You can just say that getting in shape only happens once you've done it for a longer time. I'd rather you give me the scientific basis behind it (which would much more convince me of its credibility) rather than comparing it to a glass of water that only spills after 1000 drops. Eye roll. And yes, I know that he does mention some scientific backing of the formation of habits but all the comparisons still annoyed me, and made the book way longer than it should be.Finally, I just didn't like his narration. He didn't seem excited to read this book to us. It was all very robotic and monotonous. Didn't excite me to listen to it.I know this was a rant, but as someone who loves productivity and planning and forming good habits I was keen for this book. Maybe I didn't like it because he didn't tell me anything I didn't know from before or just because I wasn't a fan of the writing/narration. But anyway, first DNF of 2021, yay!

Chẳng là, vô tình mình thấy 2 youtuber siêng năng đều đọc quyển này, nên lọc cọc tải ebook đọc thử. Bạn mình vẫn bảo: "Những người siêng thì siêng theo cùng một tạng. Còn những người lười thì lười vạn kiểu", thế nên, nhòm ngó xíu xiu vào thế giới của tụi chăm chỉ chắc cũng ổn thôi.Tựa gốc của nó là "Thói quen nguyên tử" đại loại là, những thói quen nhỏ sẽ ảnh hưởng đời bạn ra sao, nhưng qua con mắt "phải thật kêu để bán được sách" thì nó thành ra dài dằng dặc như thế. James Clear, thực ra cũng chẳng có một phát kiến gì mới, ông chỉ viết trên nền tảng những cuốn khác, đúc kết lại dựa trên chính kinh nghiệm của mình, rồi tòi ra cuốn này mà thôi.Bỏ qua phần đầu khá lê thê và kinh dị, thì những phần sau đó được viết rất rõ ràng, rành mạch (y như tên tác giả - Clear :v), truyền đạt đủ ý đến người đọc. Mình đọc một mạch trong cả buổi chiều, có lược qua vài chỗ, nhưng vẫn thấy cực kỳ thú vị. Căn bản, một thói quen (dù tốt hay xấu) được hình thành dựa trên 4 yếu tố: tín hiệu, cơn thèm muốn, phản hồi, và phần thưởng. Chẳng hạn, với thói quen nghiện ngập cafe của mình:Tín hiệu: bạn thức dậyCơn thèm muốn: bạn muốn tỉnh táoPhản hồi: Bạn uống một tách cà phêPhần thưởng: Bạn thoả mãn mong muốn được tỉnh táo. Uống cà phê dần liên kết việc thức dậy(Ví dụ trên mình lấy của youtuber nọ, chứ mình lười lắm)Đoạn sau, tác giả đi sâu phân tích từng yếu tố rồi đưa từng mẹo nhỏ, dễ ghi nhớ, dễ thực hiện lồng vào. Chẳng hạn, hãy xen kẽ điều bạn "cần" làm trước khi làm điều mình "muốn" làm: Toai sẽ chấm bài rồi mới đi coi anime :sss Hay việc cần quên đi mục tiêu mà cần nhìn vào cả một hệ thống ẩn dưới những thói quen thường ngày. Ví dụ như, thay vì nghĩ "Mình sẽ tăng cân", hãy nghĩ rằng "Người khoẻ mạnh sẽ ăn gì nhở?".Mình nghĩ, điều quan trọng của cuốn sách này không nằm ở chỗ những mẹo vặt, tip hay, mà ở chỗ nó thay đổi tư duy của người đọc một cách dần dần, từ từ, như chính cách thói quen thay đổi cuộc sống của ta. Nó vén lên bức màn "định kiến" vẫn che phủ ta bấy lâu, để sẵn sàng dấn bước vào một cuộc hành trình dài. Bởi, vạn dặm bắt đầu từ một bước chân, nhỉ?

Maybe I'm just a massive git who should not be allowed to read self-help books, but I can't figure out why people like this book so much. It was not good. I had to read over 10k student essays while I was a TA in grad school, and I gotta say...the content and writing read like a college paper (albeit a very good one) about this guy's research and personal opinions about habits. If I were to break out the content of this book, it would go something like this: 73% material that anybody with a dash of resolve already knows; 14% interesting anecdotes not always relating to habits ; 11% the author's self-promotion; and 2% useful (though not entirely new) information. Honestly, I think the more interesting under-lying message is "How to obtain notoriety and make a ton of money off of concepts already commonly understood and researched by others."I am no expert on habits and I am certainly not a writer, so criticism is not my goal. But people need to calm down about this guy. My personal opinion is that the book makes a few HUGE errors in its messaging: 1) the way to improve is to essentially trick yourself into doing good things, 2) the author regularly suggests that outward reinforcement is most effective (telling people that you are a runner will make you one), and 3) there is a complete and resounding absence of 'character' in his formula of good/bad habit creation/removal. If a person has character - an internal motivation to improve for the sake of improvement alone - then establishing good habits and removing bad ones is more than possible without having to shut off your brain. Again, I am not an expert by any means! His message simply did not match up with my perspective on human development and life in general. #peoplearedifferent.

As soon as I set down my Kindle, I realized I'm a failure. Really.Psychology books are my favorite thing in the world. Truly. I decided to get a copy of this as an e-book, although it sounds nicer to have a physical copy of the book, you can refer back to all that stuff later.It's true, everything being pointed out is the reason by all your habits. The environment, the association, keeping up a habit streak, less likely to repeat a habit if it's bad... wait. Am I just repeating the same thing over and over again?Yes... yes you are. I didn't come for the same old garbage I have been taught for years. Minus all the story times, examples, even more story times, this book would have been pocket sized. I do like me some small books, though.And the more I read the book, the more I got bored of it. Not just because of the repetitiveness but because the author keeps acting like he made an original point. Pleaseeeee man. You didn't get out of bed and say "Hey, there is something missing in my life, I've been doing everything wrong! (and thus, habits were invented)" and start writing stuff down.The book is just written by your everyday man, with a life, a job, and some extra hobbies. Some of this stuff you can easily Google and read about in a smaller article.long story short... any other self-help book but this one may really get you thinking. he's not entirely wrong, though.

Like the many self help books out there this one too focuses on how to be a better version of yourself but via building habits. Chances are if you have picked the book you already know this. The title is not misleading at all but be aware that this book would be most helpful if you have a commitment to building good (or aligned with your goals) lifelong habits. Its key idea is building identity based habits vs. outcome based habits. The author breaks down the process of habit building and for most of the book he takes you through each step or key element (4 that he identifies) each of which is a chapter. Although the book is peppered with several examples to reinforce ideas, not all of them seemed fitting to the point being made. It certainly has some helpful hacks (my favorite being habit stacking, two minute rule) , lines that I am sure would bode me well to remember, makes one aware of the subconscious cues one responds to and makes the point on the compounding effect of small habits effectively. The book is designed to be instructional with an added bonus of cheat sheet links, neat tables and bulleted summaries at the end of each chapter. Well, the book did prompt me to write my first review .. something I had been procrastinating for long , let’s see if I can keep up with the new identity .
